Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Role of Status in the Maintenance of Complex Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers want to understand better the dynamics behind the emergence and development of large communities that have served as centers binding the populations of regions into integrated societies. Such communities first emerged as much as 8,000 years ago in many parts of the world and served as the foundation for the much larger-scale societies with very complex patterns of organization in which the majority of the world's population lives today. The kinds of activities that were concentrated in these early centers varied considerably from one region to another. In some instances increasing craft specialization and economic interdependence between households across a region seem crucial. In other instances religious beliefs and ritual activities were of the utmost importance. And in still other cases, conflict and military defense and offense appear to have played a principal role. In varying combinations, these and other social relationships often created strong inequalities of several kinds around which societies were organized. Just how particular patterns came to be emphasized in different places and how they led to varying degrees and kinds of social inequalities are not well understood. This is especially true of cases in which growing social inequalities were not grounded in differences in productive activities, wealth, and standards of living among the population.

This project will pursue the possibility that in situations of relatively intense conflict, leaders in warfare acquire considerable prestige and more general authority and serve as the social centers of gravity for larger communities. As most often envisioned by researchers, such a path of development leads to increasing economic control and accumulation of wealth by these leaders, which enables them to broaden their social and political power. A prime opportunity to investigate this line of reasoning is provided by the rapid emergence of Sintashta-Petrovka societies of the southern Urals around 2000 BC. Elaborate warrior graves associated with small, compact, heavily fortified settlements indicate the social importance of war leaders, but little is known of the nature and organization of the communities they apparently led. Tightly-packed residences within small fortified areas have been studied, but held remarkably small numbers of inhabitants, probably representing only a portion of the regional populations of these polities. Previous research has failed to find much evidence of other hinterland communities in the regions around the fortified centers. But little-studied archaeological remains immediately outside the walls of the fortified centers may represent an important additional component of these communities. This research will target those remains and reconstruct the activities, statuses, and standards of living they represent and compare them to those of the people inside the fortifications. This will reveal whether the war leaders, as theorized, took on broader social and economic roles and a prestigious and became wealthy or whether a more egalitarian foundation anchored the society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social differences between individuals and households often feature prominently in the politics of the early complex societies that can be studied archaeologically, but the social and economic roles of elites and commoners in the initial establishment of centralized political organization appear to have varied substantially in different regions. Under the supervision of Dr. Robert D. Drennan, Igor Chechushkov carried out an archaeological survey and excavation in the Karagaily-Ayat River Valley, in the southern Urals, Russia, in order to investigate the relationship between social relations and subsistence management in the region's ancient societies.

Archaeologists' attention has been attracted to the appearance about 2000 B.C. in the Southern Urals of small extremely compact walled villages, without any known antecedents. Although these villages are associated with elaborate burials of clearly important individuals with bronze weaponry, chariots, and horses, the villages themselves show very little evidence of such social differentiation. These villages, to which the name Sintashta-Petrovka has been attached, thus represent a striking and sudden social change in a very unexpected location far from the productive agricultural zones where complex social organization has usually emerged. The forces that produced this social change have been unknown; even the nature of social and economic relationships between the inhabitants of these communities has been poorly understood.

Prior to this research attention has focused almost exclusively on the burials and the archaeological remains inside the walls of the villages. This research has documented a vital additional segment of these human communities, people who lived outside the walls of the compact villages. The dramatic regional population increase that the villages indicate was thus even more dramatic than previously imagined, since perhaps a third of the population living outside the village walls was uncounted in most previous research.

This research suggests that the previously uncounted third of the population were subsistence specialists focused on herding horses, sheep, goats, and especially cattle. The animals were probably taken to summer pastures, likely a few kilometers from the village, herded by this sector of the population, who lived in yurts. Those who stayed behind during summer in the village practiced various crafts, including bronze metallurgy, and likely cut hay to be stored to feed the animals through the winter. In winter, the portion of the population outside the village walls returned to the village location with the animals, who were housed in timber-frame house structures inside the walls during the winter, following a well-known northern-latitude herding practice of combining residences for people with winter barns for cattle, sheep, goats, and horses. Those who had herded the animals to summer pastures spent the winter in their yurts adjacent to the village, in the lee of the village walls sheltered from the wind. The exact relationship between those who lived within the walls and those outside remains to be determined. It is possible that the most prominent members of society and the craft specialists took cover inside the walls from cold winters, floods, and non-human and human predators, keeping the vitally important population of domestic animals close to themselves. These social elites may have played a managerial role, providing communities with knowledge and organizational wisdom. At the same time, less prominent members of communities, possibly those who were younger and less experienced, lived a more mobile life outside the walls caring for the animals that were essential to everyone's survival.

This way of life may have emerged as a wave of migrants entered the southern Urals region, giving it its first substantial human population. These migrants seem to have decided in their new locale to continue raising cattle as was common in warmer parts of the Black Sea steppe where they possibly came from, and cattle require more care to survive the harsh winter than sheep, goats, or horses do. The strategy of compact villages with a mobile herding component may have emerged to meet this challenge. In the following period (around 1700 B.C.), the nature of these communities changed dramatically, when the Sintashta-Petrovka walled villages disintegrated, and individual families started to live separately in smaller unwalled villages, although in contrast to what has usually been assumed, population numbers did not change radically.

As doctoral dissertation research, the broader impacts of the project include vital training for the doctoral candidate, as well as field experience and methodological training for five undergraduate and one graduate archaeology students. Interviews and public presentations provided an opportunity to discuss the research, and archaeological research generally, with members of the local community and the broader region.
